Guess who's back?

27/03/2013

As Rafael Nadal continues his comeback, George Barrett asks if the Spaniard can ever get back to his best

Image by

By undefined undefined

Let's be honest, who actually thought that after 222 days out with injury, Rafael Nadal would ever be able to play a tennis game competitively ever again? Nadal, who until recently was last seen on a tennis court at Wimbledon 2012 in his second round shock defeat to Lukas Rosol, has suffered lengthy spells on the sidelines in the past, including a ten week lay-off in 2009, but this most recent one lasted beyond belief. So when Nadal returned to action in a relatively low key doubles tournament in Vina del Mar, Chile, few expected great things. Now before you shout and say that I am making ridiculous claims, let's put this all into context. Nadal has won 11 grand slam titles (including an outrageous seven French Opens), been world number one and is considered among the greatest players of all time. So why shouldn't he have been able to come back from injury; after all, he's done it before? However, this spell in the medical room was his longest yet. After the disappointment of Wimbledon, Nadal pulled out of the Olympics, before announcing in September 2012 that he had a partially torn patella tendon. Now I'm no doctor, but according to a number of well-versed doctors and physiotherapists, this sort of injury is pretty serious to say the least. Surgery was briefly considered, but the idea was soon abandoned. At the time it was announced that he would return to the courts in November but, despite training in front of the media on 20 November, Nadal stated in October that he would not play in the final two tournaments of the year at the Paris Masters and in London's ATP World Tour Finals. He then hoped to make a comeback in an exhibition event in Abu Dhabi in December, but we all know that didn't happen, before Doha and the Australian at the start of 2013 were the targets. Nadal, however, argued that a stomach virus, not his knees, were the reason behind pulling out of these three tournaments. But everyone knows that you don't pull out of three tournaments, one of which is a grand slam, with a stomach virus, as Mark Petchy argued from the commentary box in Australia. This was worse than anyone had ever seen before. None of the other "Big Four" of men's tennis have been out with injury for anything like this amount of time. Roger Federer is a freak of nature having managed to stay injury free for pretty much the whole of his career, whilst Djokovic and Murray have always managed to keep their bodies in pretty good nick. So when Nadal announced that he was making a genuine comeback in Mexico not too long ago the media went mad, as expected. But Nadal was keen to downplay his return, simply stating in a press conference that he was returning with "uncertainty". The aim was to play in smaller tournaments on Nadal's favourite surface, clay, as it was more forgiving on his knees. Although he was physically back, it looked as if we wouldn't see the Nadal of old that achieved the incredible heights of a career grand slam. How wrong we were. Less than two months down the line, Nadal has just won a record 22nd ATP Masters Title at Indian Wells. What an achievement. He has now won 17 matches and lost just one this year - his best start to a season ever. Added to this, after a few tournaments on clay, Nadal won a tournament on the unforgiving American hard courts in a competition that, for the first time since Wimbledon last year, featured all of tennis' "Big Four". On his way to the Indian Wells title, he beat Federer, and, in the final, the dangerous Juan Martin Del Potro, who took out both Djokovic and Murray. He also closed out narrow matches against Tomas Berdych and Ernests Gulbis, players who have both claimed big scalps in the past. After Nadal fell to his back having sealed the title, he described the win as "one of the most emotional of my career". Quite a statement after all this great man has achieved. So the question that we must now ask is, can the Spaniard add to his already staggering tally of slams? With the French Open not far off on the horizon, the tennis season looks to be coming together rather nicely for Nadal. A record eighth title is now a genuine possibility and should be a realistic aim. Of all the contenders, Nadal must be considered the favourite to lift the title again - he has won over 98% of his matches there and Roland Garros is his backyard. Also, he recently regained the number four spot, and, after Wimbledon 2013, he has almost no ranking points to defend so the world number one spot is also a possibility, though realistically this will be far harder to regain than it will be to defend the French. A winning run could also see him challenge again at Wimbledon, which will be even more hotly contested than last year, as all the top players have a point to prove. Djokovic (the current dominant player) will be determined to regain his title, Murray, who lost in the final last year, will be desperate to win on home soil, and Federer, who just loves the strawberries and cream, will want to prove he is not too old to boss the big guns. Nadal will have some competition. He can take strength from his 2010 season, however. After facing a difficult and disappointing season with injury and family issues in 2009, Nadal bounced back fabulously the following year to win three grand slams in a row. All this must be owed to the man's mental toughness, which makes him one of the fiercest competitors on the circuit. After proving himself a master at the comeback before, he can do it again. Although overhauling Federer's record 17 grand slams is probably an achievement too far in this man's career, who can doubt that the Spanish bull can't dominate world tennis again? His return is certainly a huge boost to men's tennis. The next few months will be incredibly interesting in the world of tennis, and everyone will keenly be watching as Nadal begins the clay court build up to Roland Garros. Welcome back Rafa, welcome back.
